name: Electroacupuncture
summary: A modern variation of traditional acupuncture that applies mild electrical currents to needles inserted at acupuncture points, enhancing therapeutic effects.
description: Electroacupuncture is an adaptation of traditional acupuncture in which fine needles are inserted at specific points on the body and then connected to a device that delivers continuous, mild electrical pulses. The technique is believed to augment the effects of manual acupuncture by providing stronger and more consistent stimulation. Electroacupuncture is used to address pain, inflammation, neurological disorders, and other conditions, and is commonly applied in both integrative medicine and clinical research settings.

practice_styles: Traditional acupuncture points with electrical stimulation
treatment_variants: Transcutaneous electroacupuncture (surface electrodes instead of needles)
treatment_duration: Series of 6–12 sessions for chronic conditions
metadata.training_required: Performed by licensed acupuncturists trained in electroacupuncture safety and techniques.
metadata.regulatory_status: Widely used in integrative practices; regulated under acupuncture licensing.

contraindications: Absolute: Presence of pacemakers or implanted electronic devices
Relative: Pregnancy (especially abdominal points), seizure disorders, bleeding disorders
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when performed by trained practitioners. Risks include mild bruising, tingling, or skin irritation. Electrical stimulation contraindicated for pacemaker users.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate. Supported by systematic reviews for pain management, though quality of evidence varies. Research in neurological and systemic conditions is ongoing.

sections.text: Electroacupuncture enhances traditional acupuncture by applying electrical pulses through needles. This stimulation is believed to modulate pain pathways via endorphin release, improve circulation, reduce inflammation, and regulate nerve activity. Different frequencies may engage distinct neurochemical mechanisms.

sections.preparation: Patient is assessed for safety (screen for pacemakers, pregnancy, seizure history).
procedure: Insertion of acupuncture needles at targeted points
Adjustment of electrical current to patient tolerance
sections.frequency: 1–2 times per week for chronic conditions

items: High-frequency stimulation (50–100 Hz, acute pain relief)

rare: Infection if needles are not sterile

screening_required: Screen for pregnancy and seizure history

items: Requires extra caution with patients using pacemakers or other implanted devices.
Often reported to provide stronger stimulation than manual acupuncture.
Evidence supports use for chronic pain and nausea, with mixed findings for neurological conditions.

items.label: Vickers AJ, et al. (2018). Acupuncture for Chronic Pain: Update of an Individual Patient Data Meta-Analysis.

seo.title: Electroacupuncture – Acupuncture with Electrical Stimulation
seo.description: Electroacupuncture enhances traditional acupuncture with mild electrical currents to improve pain relief, neurological recovery, and inflammation control.
